node.title: Bushfire bunkers save lives — so why is red tape making it so hard to install them?
node.alt: A dome structure made of stone with a metallic door set into its side with a forest in the background
node.description: As another hot summer looms, a former intelligence chief warns bushfires will claim more lives if politicians fail to introduce Australia-wide bunker installation standards.
node.content:
["Political inaction to standardise fire safety bunker installations across Australia will cost lives this summer, a former intelligence chief says, as red tape and bureaucracy continue to hinder the process in bushfire-prone areas.\u00a0", "Fire bunkers in Victoria \u2014\u00a0the only state to have a formal accreditation system \u2014\u00a0saved the lives of six people who took shelter in them during the Black Summer bushfires of 2019-2020, which killed 33 people across the country.", "Accredited bunkers have since become a popular addition for property owners but people outside Victoria face a list of hurdles in the shape of building approvals, council approvals and technical assessments, that have made the process of installing one a lengthy headache.", "Adding to their woes is lukewarm enthusiasm from firefighting authorities \u2014 who fear that a bunker's addition to\u00a0a property will make some people complacent about bushfire preparedness and use it as a first resort.", "", "
Accredited bunkers must be airtight with enough oxygen for each person for at least one hour.(Supplied: Donald Graham)
", "Australian National University Centre for Military and Security Law honorary professor\u00a0Clive Williams said there should be a common federal standard for bunkers to create designs that were affordable and not over-engineered.", "\"It's all very depressing \u2014 no doubt more lives will be lost next bushfire season.\"", "
Victoria's push for regulation\u00a0
", "After 173 people died\u00a0when the Black Saturday bushfires ignited across\u00a0Victoria in 2009 \u2014 Australia's worst fires on record for loss of life \u2014\u00a0the 2009 Victorian Bushfires Royal Commission found that eight of the victims died while using informal bunkers.", "The shelters\u00a0included shipping containers, cellars and self-built bunkers.", "Recommendations were made to regulate private bushfire shelters and, as there was a lack of technical standards for the structures, the Victorian\u00a0government engaged the CSIRO and its Country Fire Authority to work towards creating some.", "In 2014, the Australian Building Codes Board (ABCB) drew from the CSIRO's\u00a0work to create a\u00a0National Construction Code (NCC) against which all bunkers must now be assessed.", "Victoria has gone a step further by\u00a0accrediting and pre-approving\u00a0commercial lines of bunkers to\u00a0streamline their\u00a0installation.", "", "
The Black Saturday bushfires of 2009 remain the worst in Australia's history due to the number of lives lost.(AFP: William West)
", "
Red tape elsewhere
", "Bunker designs outside Victoria, however, are\u00a0assessed on a case-by-case basis, such as in NSW where applicants must also get approval from their local council and meet the provisions of the Environmental Planning and Assessment Act.", "In South Australia, after documentation is lodged, the relevant council or private building certifier has to assess the proposal against the NCC.", "If this is satisfied, it will be referred to the State Planning Commission's Building Technical Panel before it goes back to the council for a final decision.", "\"Regardless of which state or territory they are built in, private bushfire shelters are considered high-risk building and require a building approval \u2014 this is the case in every state and territory, including Victoria,\" a spokesperson from the SA Attorney-General's Department said.", "", "
Accredited bunkers are typically dug into the earth in an open area.(Supplied: Wildfire Safety Bunkers)
", "But bunker manufacturer Anthony Tratt, who\u00a0owns Wildfire Safety Bunkers in Victoria, said it was \"ridiculous\" that after all the money Victorian taxpayers had spent to accredit his bunkers, they could not be readily used interstate without further technical assessments.", "\"In the early days, we tried to help our customers all over Australia with their councils and all that sort of stuff, but all we did is hit brick walls,\" Mr Tratt said.", "\"It was very thorough and there's no reason why it can't be accepted everywhere.\"", "
Bypassing red tape
", "Adelaide Hills resident and Country Fire Service volunteer *Peter found it far easier to refer to the accredited bunker he ordered from Victoria as a storage bunker rather than a personal shelter, in order to avoid the headaches the latter label would face in SA.", "He has since taken shelter in his bunker during both the 2015 Sampson Flat and 2019 Cudlee Creek bushfires and said without it, \"we would have lost our home in Sampson Flat and again in Cudlee Creek\".", "Because his property was properly cleared and his house and outhouses protected with a sprinkler system, Peter was able to turn it on, shelter in the bunker for up to an hour to wait for the outside temperature to drop below 50 degrees Celsius, and then leave the bunker\u00a0to put out spot fires.", "", "
The installation of an accredited bunker enables well-prepared residents to fight spot fires\u00a0once a front has passed.(AP: Rick Rycroft)
", "But he also recognised that if not properly designed and constructed, bunkers could be dangerous, and understood why groups like SA's CFS were \"wary\" of endorsing them, particularly if a property was not otherwise prepared.", "\"It's a scary thing, going through a bushfire, and the last thing you should do is panic and leave at the last minute, because that's when people get caught in cars, or trees come down on their roads like they did during the Sampson Flat fire.", "
Performance standards
", "", "
Larger fire bunkers can resemble storm and tornado shelters like those used overseas.(Supplied: Wildfire Safety Bunkers)
", "The ABCB Performance Standard for the Design and Construction of Private Bushfire Shelters 2014 regulates\u00a0that bunkers must be built from concrete or solid masonry, located six to 20 metres\u00a0from an associated building, and be airtight with enough oxygen for each person for one hour during which\u00a0air temperature cannot exceed 45 degrees Celsius.", "The CSIRO has warned that a bunker is not guaranteed as a life-saving measure and should not be considered an alternative to leaving early or a stand-alone solution.\u00a0", "It also said accreditation was only being provided by the Victorian Building Authority and any company that suggested the CSIRO had personally endorsed a specific product was \"incorrect\".", "
An easier way?
", "Mr Williams said the\u00a0accredited bunkers being sold commercially in Victoria were over-engineered and too expensive, and he believed a federally endorsed alternative could be produced \"for well under $1,000\".", "By way of example, he referred to the Anderson Shelters that were introduced by the British Government during World War Two, \"which was basically six pieces of curved corrugated iron that came in a kit form\".", "Londoners often buried Anderson Shelters in open space in their backyards, covering them with half a metre of earth where they proved to be \"very effective\" at protecting people from \"firestorms\".", "", "
An Anderson Shelter remains intact amidst the bombing destruction in London during 1941.(Supplied: Ministry of Information, UK, via Wikimedia Commons\u00a0)
", "Mr Williams said radiant heat from a fire was what killed people, meaning the safest place was an underground bunker in open space away from any burning debris that could fall on it.", "\"Perhaps the government could actually make some money out of it by providing the kit.", "\"Many properties would survive if someone was there to put out spot fires \u2014 it's just another example of poor state coordination and a lack of leadership.\"", "", "
Authorities believe bunkers should be just one part of a property's bushfire preparedness plan.(Supplied: Wildlife Safety Bunkers\u00a0)
", "
Federal government stays out of it
", "A Department of Home Affairs spokeswoman\u00a0did not answer questions about whether the federal government should take leadership on bushfire bunkers, or whether it would consider a national scheme to subsidise and/or distribute them.", "\"Whilst there is an Australian Building Codes Board standard for bushfire shelters, the building of these shelters must still be approved by the relevant jurisdiction.\"", "The spokeswoman said the government was \"identifying opportunities for investment in disaster risk reduction and resilience initiatives to better prepare communities for future disasters\".", "This included the $600 million \"Preparing Australia Program to improve the long-term resilience of Australian communities\".", "*Name has been changed to protect identity"]
